Articles: {"abstract": "In \u201cThe Evolution of a Corporate Idealist,\u201d a former BP employee sees globalization and the Internet as pushing more companies to social responsibility.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/09/business/bookshelf-how-big-business-can-take-the-high-road.html", "snippet": "In \u201cThe Evolution of a Corporate Idealist,\u201d a former BP employee sees globalization and the Internet as pushing more companies to social responsibility.", "lead_paragraph": "It\u2019s been a long time \u2014 maybe never \u2014 since I\u2019ve read a book that made me feel proud or even a little encouraged about the moral compass of the world\u2019s largest companies. Corporations, after all, exist to make money. Last I checked, doing good deeds is not listed as a fiduciary duty. But Christine Bader\u2019s thought-provoking book, \u201cThe Evolution of a Corporate Idealist: When Girl Meets Oil\u201d (Bibliomotion, 264 pages), argues that this may be changing, at least among some of the people who work at these companies.", "print_section": "BU", "print_page": "10", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": {"abstract": "Gyrations in the largest debt markets have undermined the concept of risk-free returns. When this last compass fails, investors will be left at sea.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/16/business/dealbook/bond-turmoil-signals-a-new-era-of-return-free-risk.html", "snippet": "Gyrations in the largest debt markets have undermined the concept of risk-free returns. When this last compass fails, investors will be left at sea.", "lead_paragraph": "United States and German government bonds are gyrating as they rarely do. Yields are shooting higher for no apparent reason, and sometimes falling back within hours for equally unclear motives. Such turbulence in the biggest and most liquid bond markets is ushering in a new era. The traditional concept of risk-free returns has been turned on its head.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Bond Turmoil Signals a New Era of \u2018Return-Free Risk\u2019", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Government Bonds", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Swiss Franc (Currency)", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Credit and Debt", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Stocks and Bonds", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-05-15T18:09:31+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Swaha Pattanaik", "person": [{"firstname": "Swaha", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Pattanaik", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/fd1bf17f-ae00-5b3f-abf0-df89d4bccb0a", "word_count": 350, "uri": "nyt://article/fd1bf17f-ae00-5b3f-abf0-df89d4bccb0a"}
